course.name: Business Ethics and the Individual
course.description: This course presents and exemplifies three major traditions of ethical thought in East and West moral philosophy - namely utilitarianism, principle-based ethics and virtue-based ethics. Employing guest speakers, lectures, cases, contemporary readings, role-plays, fieldwork, reflective student writing, and discussion groups, the course engages students in a serious consideration of their own ethical standards as applied to their present academic environment and their future careers. Students come to understand through this course that while an ethical dilemma may be viewed in various ways depending on one's guiding assumptions, a decision and course of action nevertheless must be chosen in harmony with one's own moral convictions. For Business students only.

reviews.title: JC does not know much about ethical theories, but he knows how to teach us to apply them in real life!!!
reviews.comment_content:
He is a new professor in teaching ethics, thus his teaching syllabus is different from other professors.

The first part of the course is introducing ethical theories. Such as duty theory and meta-ethics. To be honest, JC does not have the skills to properly explain and teach ethical theories. Usually, he gives us enough time for us to discuss in a small group. His lectures are well prepared and he purchased many materials such as case studies and games for better teaching.
For example, the simulation of a zombie virus outbreak, which allows us to consider real-life examples rather than teaching some boring ethical theories.
Also, JC invites students to conducts personality tests when teaching Virtue Theories, which is quite interesting.

The midterm exam is an exam that requires students to understand the ethical theories.

After that, we have a session of research skill teaching workshop, and the good thing is we can go back and review it at any time.

The second half of the course is the application of ethics, i.e. debate.
JC releases all the topics and the materials, all the students are free to choose which case for debate. The debate structure is UK and East coast US style, which is just each side expressing their argument without any free debate time. For details please go to read the syllabus.
After the debate, we have free discussion time where students can freely speak their own opinions for Participation Credits.
(Pro tips: Don't rely on the case study as the debate topic is not usually directly related, do your own research instead.)

The original plan for the final exam was a two-hour in-class exam. But somehow JC has decided to provide us with a 3.5 days take-home assignment. The questions are quite easy and students are free to write their own points such as challenging the question as long as the claims are valid.

E.g.:In the case "Sons and Daughters", his final summary is hiring clients' sons and daughters while don't act like some foolish banks who left much evidence from it.  That is the true practice !!!!

The true goal of ethical courses is to teach us to do illegal and unethical things legally. And he is constantly teaching us that.

reviews.author: Bibo
reviews.title: Very unclear grading, broken grade
reviews.comment_content: Mainly talk about business morals and controversies. Should not be boring. Although it does not really look at them in details.
reviews.comment_teaching: The in-class teaching is quite good. The topics are not boring and they are all worthwhile to take a look at. Mark encourages discussion in the class. However the guidance on how to complete the course work is extremely unclear. There is very limited guidance on how to complete the project. There is only one short meeting with the TA before the actual presentation of the group project. The TA is just doing it to report the progress of each group to MARK, without really offering any help. The guideline on integrated task is even poorer as there is no guideline.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is really subjective and unpredictable. You can't even have a correct expectation towards your grade until it strikes you. There is no grades released for the weekly posting, the integrated test nor the presentation. What's so disastrous about the weekly posting is that there is no clear instruction of when-when is counted as "a week". So some people assume that it will be sun-sat while the others would assume that is mon-sun. The problem of having a wrong assumption is that you will miss some weeks if you do not post on the exact some day every week. Another thing is class participation. Every 2% will be deducted for every lesson missed. However, in this term, we don't have iPRS as classes are conducted online. Therefore you won't know if late would be counted as absence, and how many minutes should be considered as "late" as well. For the integrated test, the instruction is super unclear that you won't even know what to write for it. There is no marking for the integrated test either so you wouldn't know how you performed. The same happens to group project. There is no grade for the project nor the presentation. Overall speaking, the transparency of this course grading is extremely poor. I got a C+ and I had no idea what had happened.
reviews.comment_workload: If you aim for a good grade, the workload can be heavy. Otherwise, the workload is just mild and you can expect to get a C. First of all class participation is required. Otherwise 2% will be deducted for each class missed and that is disastrous. Also, there is weekly discussion. If you miss it, your grade will be heavily affected as well. You will need to study the reading materials before every lecture so that you can complete the weekly posting and the integrated test, which can actually be quite demanding. The workload for the group project isn't really heavy and I would say it's easy to handle. For this semester, we can decide on the business controversy ourselves and we only need to dig into the pros and cons, the stakeholders and our stance supported by several examples over the world.

reviews.comment_grading:
To be honest, the grading is not that transparent for this course since I only received the marks of my Progress Report...

Participation (40%):
It includes online discussion, in-class discussion and class attendance as well. Please make sure you do not skip any of the classes as missing one of them would cost you 2% of the final grade. From my point of view, it's worthwhile to spend the 2-hour time with Mark in class (despite of taking the attendance) as he lectures well and speaks fluent and clear english which you would rarely encounter in UST's courses.

And you should be voicing out your opinion at least once per week towards a particular topic in the online discussion. Try not to skip the online discussion cuz Mark would really read the discussion board and jot down everyone's name!

AESP Project (40%)
You have to find a small shop in HK and help facilitate their business growth. Try not to be that ambitious as you only have limited time and manpower.

Final Exam (20%)
A open-book final exam with essay questions only. The whole final exam would be based on the weekly assigned readings. You will be fine if you  can skim through them before you sit for the exam and at least understand what those theories are talking about. Need not to pressurize yourself cuz it's an open-book exam and probably everyone would receive similar score.

Participation: 40%
(a) Online Discussion Forum -  20%
(b) In-class Participation - 20%
AESP Project: 40%
- Progress Report
- Presentation ( assign 1/2 groupmates to present)
- Final Report
Final Exam: 20%

I attended all the lectures and spoke in class once for the every other week (it's a rough estimate, cuz I only speak if I have something to say and purely based on my mood haha).
For the online discussion, I commented on the discussion board almost every week and probably I've missed 2-3 times due to procrastination :(
I also did the presentation with my other groupmate, but it's purely optional since Mark said that the whole group would receive the same grade for presentation.

Final grade: A-
*I could probably score higher if I could type in the discussion board every week and speak more in class; lamentably, I am an introvert :(
The grading is totally non-transparent as mentioned. Just do your best and God will do the rest.
reviews.comment_workload:
Personally speaking, I think the workload is very heavy and it just looks like a 4-credits course than a 2-credits course.

The project itself is tough and it also depends on what your client demands from your group.
At the same time, you should be typing on the discussion board every week (I think it's not a good idea to skip it because Mark would really read it every week and jot down your names), not to mention those weekly assigned readings which would be tested in final exam.

This course doesn't teach anything concrete or useful. Around 60-70% of lesson time is reserved for "bullshitting time" when everyone can discuss the pros and cons of some business ethics topics (eg. "Should whistleblowers get paid?"). The professor didn't do much wrap-ups or reflections after each discussion ends and I feel like these discussions exist for the sake of existing. The course also didn't really teach much ethical theories and most of the theories are taught at the first 2~3 weeks.   This may be good if you hate learning boring theories 🤣
reviews.comment_teaching:
🔶 Professor
I'd say his teaching is okay since he is enthusiastic and very interactive with the students. He encourages discussion in the class by asking everyone to share their thoughts on ethical controversies. His English is also very fluent since he is a Canadian.

However, if you are an introverted student who never speaks in class like me, you would find the lesson very boring. It feels like the things they're discussing is unimportant.


🔶 TA
The TA is friendly and nice. You only need to attend 2 tutorial sessions and meet the TA for 15 minutes. Your group need to report your project progress to the TA in the second tutorial. Even though our group hadn't even started doing anything when we met the TA, he was perfectly fine with that xD
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is extremely NON-TRANSPARENT since they didn't release ANY of your marks and it's also subjective. I got a B+ and I have no fucking idea why I got this grade 🤷‍♂️🤷‍♂️🤷‍♂️

Grading Scheme (ONLINE Semester)
🔹 Online discussion board - 30%
🔹 Group presentation - 35%
🔹 Integrated test (essay writing) - 35%
🔴 -2% of final score for every SKIPPED lesson/tutorial

📃 Online Discussion Board (30%)
There are 3 discussion topics for each week and you need to submit at least one posting for EVERY WEEK. They didn't tell how your postings will be graded too. Time to practice your bullshitting skills here.

📃 Group Presentation (35%)
You'll be randomly assigned to teams of 6 and come up with a business ethics controversy to present for 10 minutes. The team need to come up with a topic with the format similar to online discussion topics (eg. "Should companies use false advertising?"). Then, discuss this controversy in both pro and con sides, then finally make a group position.

📃 Integrated Test (30%)
The test is done at the final lesson where you have 2 hours write an essay. There are 2 prompts to choose from and you need to make reference to TWO assigned readings. They are open-ended questions that asks you to discuss ways to combat unethical behaviors in workplace.

🔴 Attendance Policy
Your final grade will be DEDUCTED for 2% for EVERY SKIPPED LESSON / TUTORIAL!! The professor is scummy enough to hide this information in the middle of the course syllabus document 😈😈 I saw that there were at least 10 people not attending in every lesson...
reviews.comment_workload:
I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND taking this course when we still have online teaching due to the pandemic since the time-consuming AESP project is cancelled.

The workload is average for a 2-credit course. You need to write 1 online discussion post and go through 1 reading material each week, which takes around 15 minutes each. reviews.comment_content:
Basically, the syllabus structure is about teaching + applying.
At first, he would teach us the following normative and meta-ethics:
- Normative Ethics: Virtue Theories
- Normative Ethics: Duty Theories
- Normative Ethics: Consequentialism
- Meta-ethics & the Cultural Context
As well as a library research methods lecture, covering some very useful research platforms that can be directly accessed through the hkust library portal. And the PPT used during the research lecture would be given later so we can go back and check any time.

Then we would have a chance to practice the ethical theories later in the course in the form of group debating. We get to choose the topic early in the semester and the case materials are given for our reference. However, you could choose your groupmates as everybody had the access to the topic excel sheet, in which we typed our names under the topic.
*For this semester, I found a pattern that students in the same topic will be separated into two teams by the order that the names were typed.
i.e. first 7 names typed were in one group and the rest 7 names were in another group.

Then there were 2 mid-terms. Mid-term 1 is a closed-book MC exam including 25 MCQs and we had 60 mins to complete. And those questions can have multiple answers (Yes, you heard it right, MCs in MCs)
Mid-term 2 is a take-home essay, an argumentative essay with max. 1500 words. The essay structure is actually similar to the Opening part of the debate.
reviews.comment_teaching:
JC is really good at teaching. To be honest, the content itself is not really interesting but JC makes it enjoyable to attend the lectures. When explaining those ethical concepts, he would give some real-life examples that students can relate to. You can easily understand what he is talking about as he does not speak in monotone.

What makes his ethical lesson special is that he does teach us how to apply it in lifelike settings, so you can use them flexibly.

We are given some ethical questions to discuss during the class most of the time. It does help us in understanding the concept as JC would push us to think further. However, it left just adequate time for JC to explain the concepts. Thus, you may need to study some theories in-depth outside of the classroom.
reviews.comment_grading:

Mid-term 1: 15%
Mid-term 2: 25%
Debate: 30%
Participation: 20%

reviews.author: animej
reviews.title: Great course, great professor
reviews.comment_content:
She covered topics such as the Enron scandal, MeToo movement, Mercedes Benz scandal, studies on morality and the ethics of AI and technology. I know some people found the content useless, but personally, I found the class content to be quite interesting. She had guest speakers from Monetary Authority and the ICAC which was quite interesting. Unfortunately the MA speaker session was on the night before a midterm (that I think most of the class had), so the time wasn't very convenient.

I know some people skipped classes, but I would recommend going to class. In lectures there are in-class exercises worth 10% (which is difficult make up for with online participation if you miss it), and you need to know what topics are covered in class to know what to write in your individual essay at the end (which is worth 15%). The reading material uploaded on canvas doesn't cover everything discussed in lectures, and some of it covers topics that weren't discussed in lectures, so you would need to attend lectures to know which topics were covered in class.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Maddy is quite engaging in lessons. She likes to keep the atmosphere casual and encourages different opinions. In class she uses powerpoints, videos and games to keep the class interesting.

To record how many times we contribute in her class, she gives us post-it notes to write down our names, which she collects at the end of the lesson, so any contribution you make will definitely be recorded. She also tries to pick people that haven't contributed much to give everyone a fair chance.

Maddy is a nice professor and tries her best to help students. She is very lenient. For the AESP project, she told us that in the event of unforeseen events (e.g. an NGO at the last minute no longer wants to co-operate with us), she would not penalise us for that, and would rather focus on how we overcame the challenge. Even after the deadline, she will encourage us to hand in assignments or finish surveys, but with a penalty of course (if you're late).

In the beginning, I was a little worried about being in her class because I had no idea whether she would be a good professor as she is new to HKUST. However, I am quite happy with my choice.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course is graded based on:
Group Project (30%)
- progress report (5%)
- presentation (5%)
- AESP final report (20%)

Individual component (50%)
- individual essay (15%)
- AESP reflection (10%)
- Reflection Surveys (15%)
- In-class exercises (10%)

Participation (20%)
- in class or online participation

In the reflection survey, you need to reflect on your AESP project and your groupmates, so if you have a freerider in your group, or you are a free rider, Maddy/TA will know about it.

I was initially quite worried about my grade as I knew my group didn't do well AESP project. We ended up getting the lowest score in the class. However in the individual component, I scored the highest in the class and ended up with an A. So I'm quite happy with my score.
reviews.comment_workload:
The AESP is quite time consuming. In Maddy's class, your AESP group is assigned randomly, so hope that you won't be put with freeriders, otherwise the project will be stressful.

But other than the AESP project, I would say that the workload is pretty low. Compared with other classes, I think our workload was slightly lower. In Paul Forster's class, they had a midterm and had to write an essay in the beginning of the term (I think it was about the ethics of an industry or sth).

reviews.author: ANormalPerson
reviews.title: Be special to get good grade
reviews.comment_content:
Business ethics and moral decisions, current business affairs, some basic philosophies.

There will be several sessions in one lesson:

4. Corporate Values

reviews.comment_teaching:
Mark is a good teacher for sure.

He tries to get students speaking and expressing their thoughts and values. He is a knowledgeable person who reads tons of news, so he could react to most of the things students said during lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Participation (In-class and online discussion)
20% Integrated Test
50% AESP Group Project

All the scores are not announced except the first progress report of the AESP Group Project. In my view, my group and I tried to stand out of others and by this way we got outstanding grades.

To get good grades in participation, you should speak as much as possible during lessons. Read news before each lessons and be brave enough to speak up. Do not miss any online discussions (although I missed 2) and you can get good grades.

Final Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload heavily depends on your AESP project.

First, the owner of business owners that you will co-operate with can demand you to do many things. If you are unlucky, you may encounter those who treat you like free labour. Our "partner" call of a change of our groups' design for 10+ times. It is basically a disaster for designers in the group.

Second, the online discussion forum requires you to do weekly discussions. You react to the topic others raised or what others had said. It will take some time if you try to stand out from all the discussions, as your paragraph has to be longer and more inspiring. I really dug through my brain and wrote around 15 lines of words every week. It was a little bit time-consuming for me.

Third, there are readings distributed after every lesson. They are usually around couple pages long and will be used for in-lesson discussion and the integrated test. Frankly speaking I only read them the day before the test but I do feel I could learn more if I read them every week.

reviews.author: hungrypotato
reviews.comment_content:
Covers many interesting topics, such as trolleyology, peer pressure and decision makings, ethics in value chains, ethics of superheros and much more. His lecture powerpoints do not have much content (usually just photos), so make sure to attend classes to make sure you know what is being taught.

From what I heard, Paul's class is one of the most interesting among other professors, as he uses a lot of examples from comics and movies.
reviews.comment_teaching: Paul is extremely interesting. He uses Marvel superheros to bring out ethical concepts. He is also friendly and engaging and tries to remember his students' names. He also shares his personal experiences but makes sure he is on topic and does not go off-track. One lesson was used to play a movie related to business ethics. He also plays a lot of videos in class so make sure class content is interesting. He asks questions quite frequently and invites students to contribute their ideas. He never disagrees with what students say, and guides students to justify their opinions.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation (Attendance, Classroom Discussions): 15%
Ethics Cafe Online Forum: 15%
Integrated Test: 20%
AESP Group Project: 50%, including:
- Progress report: 5%
- Final Presentation: 5%
- Final Report: 40%

Since there are many students in class who answer questions proactively, I thought Paul can't remember people's names and therefore class participation meant nothing. But apparently the TA sits at the very back of the classroom to mark who answered questions.

Ethics forum is EXTREMELY important. I got a friend who skipped most forum and got C range in the end despite doing very well in the AESP project. Need to do forum once per week, and make sure the content is good. Total number of posts needed was 10, so we could skip 2 weeks.

Integrated test covers class content pretty well. Paul uploads practice papers - MAKE SURE you do them. He basically copied and pasted one part of the practice paper to the integrated test, just with slightly different choices. Also remember the writing framework for analysing ethical issues (the framework appears in his notes quite frequently)

Project is VERY important. My group screwed up group presentation, but luckily our reports were at least average. Make sure to take more photos for the "verification" part of the project. And do not choose random services to do - try to choose things that are related to ethics even though it's hard, otherwise in the "ethics part" of the report, you can only "blow water" and it's hard to get high marks.
reviews.comment_workload:
AESP project was horribly busy. My group had many free riders and only 1 or 2 people were working constantly. Paul doesn't let people choose their own groups (draw lots), but you can secretly swap lots with someone. But the workload for other professors is similar as all classes have to do AESP Project.

Ethics cafe is done weekly, but Paul does not require long arguments, so the workload for that part is okay. Just make sure not to deadline fight and find better groupmates, and then AESP project should be okay.

reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_grading:
50% AESP
30% In-class Participation and Online Discussion Board
20% Integrated Task

For the AESP, groups are assigned at random. However, variance in reports and presentations is not significant. Therefore, handing in the reports on time, and writing enough will lead to a satisfactory score. AESP is not the key to getting a good grade. There is no evaluation session and the instructor would not acknowledge your contribution to the group. Of course, being the group leader of the project will result in a slightly better grade.

Attendance is crucial for Mark's class. Missing one lesson is almost equivalent to 2% of final score. Don't miss lectures and tutorials! Otherwise, it will be nearly impossible to achieve A range. In-class Participation does not really help as Mark would not remember your name unless you are making a really good answer. Students are generally very active in answering questions, therefore, it is very hard to distinguish yourself from the crowd through answering questions. However, participation in the Online Discussion Board is essential for getting even satisfactory grades. You should at least write a passage on the board per week. At least one per week.

Integrated Task is easy and is basic essay-writing. Everybody gets similar grades and does not make much difference in the overall grade. Just be all-rounded and logically correct in your writing.

I was not the group leader.
I got B+

You have to make tough decisions in order to prevent or delay a zombie outbreak from spreading in your fictional country.

reviews.comment_teaching:
David is the nicest professor in HKUST! He teaches very well, has good PPTs, and also replies quickly in emails. Best of all, he provide RVC on Canvas! Additionally you don't need to book appointments with him, you can just walk up to his office and have a chat about life!!!

Furthermore, he proclaimed himself as a master procrastinator, and he understands the mindsets of students that procrastinate. As a result, he gives numerous extensions even for the simplest of reasons, and he rescheduled the integrated test for people who were sick during April/May.

In the integrated test, he gives out free snacks and drinks to everyone!!! Thanks David!!!

reviews.comment_grading:
Good grading if you understand the content. Memorising is not required, but you need to have a clear and open mind when doing the final project and integrated test. The integrated test is closed book so the cutoff are more wider.

10% 6 Weekly Reading Quizzes (10%)
10% 2 Short Quizzes 5 MCs each
30% 2 Assignments
25% Group Project
25% Integrated Test

Weekly Quizzes: Very misleading, I got 5/6 even though they were super easy.
Short Quizzes: First is easy (I got 5/5, mean around 3/5), Second is impossible (I got 4/5 fluke, mean around 2/5)
Assignments: Very lenient, I got basically full for both.
Final Project: Looking at previous years, if you make a compelling simulation, it should be above 40/50.

Integrated Test: 2 hours closed book, 35% MCQ/Fill in the blanks, 65% Long questions. I write a lot (too much that David added a warning in the extra pages saying "you should probably stop writing").

As the exam is closed book, the cutoff should be different to previous years (which were online and open book).

I assume that I did good in the project and test. Finally I get A-range.
reviews.comment_workload:
For a 2 credit course, the workload is more like 3 credit course. The official contact time is 2 hours per week. But, there is reading material every week which are tested in the reading quizzes or the integrated test.

You also need to arrange times to meet with partner (for assignment 1) or groups (for assignment 2 and final project). Otherwise, the assignments are really easy to complete.

The final project is due during the exam period, so I recommend to start early!!! You have to come up with a full simulation with plot, confidential information, outcomes, and teaching instructions. In 10 pages, my group wrote almost 4000 words!!!

You also cannot 'properly' revise the integrated test as the long questions are always different. In fact, its better to try understand every concept by reading the reading materials and ppt. DO NOT JUST 'MEMORIZE'!

Tip: As David teaches and marks 300 students, it is recommended that your responses are unique and different to your classmates. That way, he will be less bored and may give you better marks (especially in long questions).

reviews.title: The best teacher in my first sem at UST
reviews.comment_content: Business ethics and the individual? Seems pretty useless. And it might seem like that the professors were forced to teach this course just for the sake of teaching it but Mark does a great job with making it interesting. He constantly updates his PPTs with relevant business world stories and really tries to engage his students.
reviews.comment_teaching: Like I said, he's the best teacher I've had so far. Native english skills, pretty cool guy and quite friendly. He divides his class by giving a quick tip to help you adapt to university in the first few minutes, gives another few to encourage students to share some ideas or thoughts on a news article they read out of class. Then he goes on with his PPT slide about no cellphones in class. Then he starts the lecture by talking himself for 30 minutes while forcing you to either 1. discuss with a partner, 2. discuss in a group, 3. discuss in other groups. There will also be quick in class debates.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was fair to be honest; however, it seems that many of my upperclassmen hated the grading. In the end, it really comes down to how active you are in class and your AESP project. Just don't be shy, don't take out your cell phone, don't chat randomly in class, don't be late and you can get A.

Participation/class marks is very important because it makes you stand out from the other people that sit in the back and chat. Just raise your hand at every opportunity until he gets sick of seeing your hand. Also, aim to share at least 5 news articles that you've read outside of class.

The AESP project contributes to 40% of your grade and thats basically what he looks at the most. It consists of a progress report (1-2 pages, he gives you the format), a presentation (not graded), and a final report. Our group did a half-hearted job on our progress report and scored 50% on it only because we used the wrong template and had to come up with something during class. Our presentation wasn't top notch either; however, it surely was better than the presentations of the other groups. The report was well written (partly because I was the one writing most of it).

There usually is a test/ in class essay near the finals. This year we wrote an essay about in class articles we read, last year it was a MC test. It changes.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. Weekly readings and news articles that you should be prepared to discuss in class
2. AESP project presentation + report (this took the most time), while he says that the presentation is not graded, you should aim to do a good job because it will leave him with a good impression.
3. AESP Progress update report
